issues.title: Decide on a title
issues.author: SECtim
issues.body: So far, I've put "OAuth 2.0 Security Best Current Practice" as the title, but it might make sense to use a different title to at least indicate that this is an extension of an existing document of that name.

comments.author: KevinLuo2000
comments.body:
Based on the published BCP "suites" in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/bcp, a straightforward title would probably be "Updates to OAuth 2.0 Security Best Current Practice".

However, if we use the general title format "Updates to xxx", we should consider what yet another BCP document under [BCP 240](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/bcp240/) would be like. "Second Round of Updates to OAuth 2.0 Security Best Current Practice" sounds weird.

comments.author: SECtim
comments.body: I also thought about the "Update to..." title option, but came to the same conclusion - I think it's best we leave as-is for now and explicitly ask the WG for their opinion once we put out the first individual draft.

comments.author: KevinLuo2000
comments.body:
Yes, I agree that we should ask WG for their opinion.

What about changing the title to "Updates to ..." for now? I was just thinking that having the same title as the published RFC9700 might cause confusion, making people think that it's the same document, or that we are proposing to obsolete the original RFC or going to repeat the unchanged sections.

issues.title: What RFCs should this document update?
issues.author: SECtim
issues.body:
"Update" in the RFC "updates" list sense.

We certainly have 6749, 9700, and 6750 (due to the "Mix-Up Reloaded" issuer sharing cases, where a client ends up sending a bearer token to the wrong RS, thereby leaking it).

Probably also 7521, 7522, and 7523 (or, at the very least, 7523).

Anything else?

comments.author: SECtim
comments.body: Probably also PAR

issues.author: SECtim
issues.body:
(This is part of the feedback by @adon-at-work)
- 2.1.2.1 Reminder about validating issuer field from metadata file, as per [rfc8414#section-3.3](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8414#section-3.3). Reminder for not to extract issuer from the token_endpoint string (engineer may be tempted to do so given their current implementation).

issues.title: Discuss "single value audience" requirements
issues.author: SECtim
issues.body:
(This is part of the feedback by @adon-at-work)
2.1.2.2 aud=single target endpoint
- single audience requirement. multiple audiences I think isn't necessarily a bad thing, as long as they are all belonging to the same issuer. ex. [[h-as.com/token](http://h-as.com/token), [h-as.com/revoke](http://h-as.com/revoke)]
- What's the expectation if I need a cla for token negotiation and then later for revocation. I kinda think it could be a transactional process, I got a token, finish my task, and do clean up. I think it makes sense to reuse the same cla for both. But if its single aud, then i gotta create cla twice, one per endpoint. This can discourage people to cleanup/call revoke given the performance penalty (jti was introduced there for performance/replay reason).
- let's say we want to allow multiple aud from the same issuer. or more generally, as is today, when people put multiple aud, what's one-time use of `jti`mean? is that one-time use per aud, or across all audiences. should we clarify?

comments.author: SECtim
comments.body:
> multiple audiences I think isn't necessarily a bad thing, as long as they are all belonging to the same issuer

That would require normative changes to the AS; i.e., the AS then MUST verify that it can identify with _all_ elements in the `aud` array before accepting a client assertion (or, maybe better: all elements must be endpoints of the AS). Not necessarily a reason to not include this proposal, but something to be aware of.

> But if its single aud, then i gotta create cla twice, one per endpoint.

Only when using the "exact endpoint" audience defense, i.e., when no issuer identifier is available.

> This can discourage people to cleanup/call revoke given the performance penalty (jti was introduced there for performance/replay reason).

I wouldn't say that `jti` was introduced to enable replay - actually, quite the opposite: To (at least optionally) prevent replay. For example, the default for [OpenID Connect authentication JWTs](https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-core-1_0.html#ClientAuthentication) is "These tokens MUST only be used once". In the IETF world, the usual formulation is something like "MAY use `jti` to ensure that JWTs are not replayed", e.g., in [RFC7519](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7519#section-4.1.7), [RFC7521](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7521#section-5.1), [RFC7522](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7522#section-3), [RFC7523](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7523#section-3), and [RFC9449](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9449#name-dpop-proof-jwt-syntax).

> let's say we want to allow multiple aud from the same issuer. or more generally, as is today, when people put multiple aud, what's one-time use of jti mean? is that one-time use per aud, or across all audiences. should we clarify?

That's a can of worms this document certainly should not open, because it has nothing to do with audience injection attacks or their mitigation.
That said, in my opinion, the original formulations around `jti` and JWT replay/reuse are somewhat unfortunate, because they end up saying "do whatever you want" (with the exception of OIDC, but that also leaves the door open to "unless conditions for reuse were negotiated between the parties"), instead of giving clear options with their respective pros and cons.

---

So, to summarize what I think:
- This document should definitely avoid talking about `jti` and JWT replay/reuse.
- I am in principle open to discuss the possibility of allowing `aud` arrays, but at least for RFCs 7521, 7522, 7523, and 9126, as well as the OIDF specs OIDC, CIBA, FAPI 1.0, and FAPI 2.0, corresponding updates/drafts thereof do require single-valued audiences; so talking about multi-valued `aud`s here might confuse people.

comments.author: adon-at-work
comments.body:
>  use jti to ensure that JWTs are not replayed

Sure. I should word it more carefully. I meant "jti was introduced there for (trading off between) performance/replay reason". Performance-critical applications may not want to use `jti`, where security-critical applications use `jti` to prevent replay.

There were (at least) two specs regarding `jti`
- https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7519#section-4.1.7 says `jti` is optional, whereas
- https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-core-1_0.html#ClientAuthentication says `jti` is required 

I missed the 2nd spec initially, and thought that most people aren't using `jti` since it's optional (given that replay is, to certain degree, mitigated by `exp` already). So I raised the concerns. 

Since `jti` is already a required thing in the context of using jwt as client authentication, then I assume people is likely re-generating a new cla fresh anyway whenever it hits an endpoint. So, I agree we should not bring up `jti`.

issues.title: Clarify that proposed fixes do not require AS changes
issues.author: SECtim
issues.body:
@adon-at-work's initial feedback includes:

> Draft does NOT mention the need for AS server change. But the openid letter clearly spells it out.
> - Should AS change its enforcement first (ex. accepting token endpoint today but some clients are presenting aud=issuer)? Or should clients go first? It’s practically impossible to coordinate so many parties to agree on a change, even more unlikely to happen at the same time. Then people will naturally ask for backward compatibility.
> - Think about the owner of the malicious AS, he will likely have no incentive to update… but will come up with all kinds of excuses like I can’t update because I have no engineering resources… Will client still need to send token_endpoint to those not updating yet?

=> Draft should state and explain why the "aud = issuer identifier" and "aud = exact endpoint" defenses do not require any AS changes.

issues.title: Discuss proposed alternative defense
issues.author: SECtim
issues.body:
(This is part of the feedback by @adon-at-work)

> Easiest and most pragmatic solution that works overnight, that requires only client changes. Client ensures that there’re no overlaps of client_id and token_endpoint pairs for all its ASes (be it existing ones or those by DCR in the future). Unlikely there’s a legit use case where the pair would be the same across two different issuers. Should there be an existing collision, as a remedy, the app can re-register to get a new client_id over DCR from one of the issuers (the legit one is unlikely to reuse client_id) to make things unique.

Think about whether this works and what the client has to watch out for. If viable as a defense, consider adding it.

comments.author: SECtim
comments.body: Also consider ecosystems that always use the same client_id across ASs (e.g., OpenID Federation).

comments.author: SECtim
comments.body:
> requires only client changes

That is also true for the "aud = issuer identifier" and "aud = exact endpoint" defenses (see #12).

> Client ensures that there’re no overlaps of client_id and token_endpoint pairs for all its ASes

I actually think that's not sufficient to prevent audience injection attacks, at least not in general. Consider a client that always includes the token and revocation endpoints in its client assertions (which is perfectly fine w.r.t. the relevant standards). In that case, the attacker AS can publish the following metadata (excerpt):
```
token_endpoint: att.com/token,
revocation_endpoint: hon.com/token
```
The client's token request (to what the client thinks is the attacker AS) goes to `att.com/token` (i.e., to the attacker) and includes a client assertion with `aud: ["att.com/token", "hon.com/token"]`. That `aud` value is also valid for requests to `hon.com/token` (and maybe other endpoints of `hon.com` as well, see #8). Hence, this is an instance of an audience injection attack.

Without AS changes, most combinations of endpoints with client authentication can be (ab)used in one way or the other by an attacker to obtain a client assertion that's valid somewhere else _unless_ the client chooses an `aud` value that's either the issuer identifier or the exact target endpoint. Hence, I'd be very careful in trying to come up with some "clever" way for the client to ensure its AS registrations are "not attackable" (and, what's more: Any such requirement on the client would be in conflict with the current and widely implemented logic of "client ID and AS endpoints are provided by the AS and (mostly) opaque values to the client" with only very minimal restrictions, such as mandatory HTTPS for the token endpoint).

Also note that just doing another round of DCR - even if feasible, think of stuff like initial access tokens that are typically one-time use - is not at all guaranteed to result in a different client ID. In some cases, having the same client ID for all registrations of a given client (even across ASs) is mandatory, e.g., in OpenID Federation.

I.e., I think this mechanism might introduce problems in practice and, more importantly, doesn't reliably work as a defense.

comments.author: adon-at-work
comments.body:
I agree with everything you said. 

But as I emphasized, the alternative defense is a **quick-and-dirty** fix (and surely it comes with all those "cleverness" concerns here and there as you tried to enumerate...). 

The fundamental difference between our believes may be that I assume a change to `aud=token_EP` will introduce backward compatibility issues, since most (or at least some) ASes accept `aud=token_EP` **only**, as influenced and suggested by many of those specs. But apparently, you seem to expect *all* ASes to readily take any values that identify themselves (could be issuer, token_EP, par_EP, etc, and so no AS change is needed). 

If the assumption is right, there will be compatibility issue. So in this imperfect world, what can a client do to secure itself while still keeping the lights on when these "standard-non-compliant" servers will only accept "aud=token_EP"?

> Without AS changes, most combinations of endpoints with client authentication can be (ab)used in one way or the other by an attacker to obtain a client assertion that's valid somewhere else unless the client chooses an aud value that's either the issuer identifier or the exact target endpoint.

Agree. Multiple values in aud is asking for trouble.

I see here you're implicitly expecting client to use a **single** aud value for your solution to be secured too. If a client uses the same client_id across all ASes and include all issuers in its `aud=[issuer1, issuer2]`, then it can be screwed too. 

Similarly, the alternative fix is meant for a vulnerable client that uses a **single** `aud = token_EP`. If we want to generalize, it could be said as "there’re no overlaps of client_id and token_endpoint (or whatever values client use in the aud) pairs for all its ASes". But of course, this discussion is meaningful only if you're convinced about the backward compatibility issue.

comments.author: SECtim
comments.body:
> fundamental difference between our believes

I agree that we seem to have different believes 😄 

> a change to aud=token_EP will introduce backward compatibility issues, since most (or at least some) ASes accept aud=token_EP only, as influenced and suggested by many of those specs. But apparently, you seem to expect all ASes to readily take any values that identify themselves (could be issuer, token_EP, par_EP, etc, and so no AS change is needed).

My take on this is twofold: First, the "expectation" that an AS will accept the exact target endpoint and its issuer identifier as `aud` is a normative requirement in all specs (that I am aware of) outside of the "original culprits (OIDC, RFCs 752x)" that do say something about the `aud` values an AS has to accept (RFC 9126 and CIBA) contain a sentence like: _"the authorization server MUST accept its issuer identifier, token endpoint URL, or pushed authorization request endpoint URL as values that identify it as an intended audience."_ (quote is from the Pushed AuthZ Request RFC)

Second, in any case, I think we do agree that the current normative language around what `aud` values an AS is allowed to accept does not conflict with the proposed fixes, i.e., they do not require normative changes to the AS.

> So in this imperfect world, what can a client do to secure itself while still keeping the lights on when these "standard-non-compliant" servers will only accept "aud=token_EP"?

If you as a client are willing to continue using an AS that
1. Requires authentication at more than the token endpoint;
2. Expects its token endpoint as the sole `aud` value at ALL these endpoints (keep in mind, for at least CIBA and PAR, an AS is _explicitly_ required to accept the respective exact endpoint as `aud`);
3. Does not care enough about its clients' security to change what `aud` values it accepts; and 
4. Does not offer a way for you as a client to update your registered key material
   1. Note 1: the current text explicitly mentions the possibility of using different key material for each AS as an alternative defense
   2. Note 2: it is sufficient if the AS just allows the client to rotate their authentication public key, i.e., the AS does not need to support full-blown Dynamic Client Management or similar (and while not _required_ in any spec that I know of - albeit some specs like RFC 7591, OIDC, and OIDC DCR do explicitly mention key rotation, FAPI 2.0 SP "recommends" it - I think we can agree that not allowing key rotation is a red flag in the first place)

... then yes, the currently proposed fixes cannot be applied to all communication with that particular AS.
That said, I'd argue that this is such a special case that it does not justify including a defense...
- That will only work in this very particular special case (assuming that some other things are clarified, e.g., the handling of `mtls_endpoint_aliases`),
- Relies on the AS continuing to only accept its token endpoint,
- Should certainly NOT be used when any other defense is available,
- Relies on the client not doing "strange, but technically allowed" things when talking to the attacker AS (like using the attacker AS' PAR endpoint as an `aud` value for requests to other endpoints of the attacker AS; note that it is the attacker who "defines" what it wants from the client, so if the client wants to talk to the attacker AS, it has to comply), and
- Breaks currently allowed setups where multiple perfectly honest, standards-compliant ASs may share a token endpoint (probably not a _common_ case, but allowed nonetheless).

... in a BCP update. Including a "quick and dirty" works-in-some-scenarios-but-not-in-others defense has huge potential for confusion - and I'd expect to then see clients implement this less-than-ideal defense, but never re-evaluating whether an actual fix can be deployed at a later time.

> But of course, this discussion is meaningful only if you're convinced about the backward compatibility issue.

As of right now, I am not really convinced that backward compatibility will be a huge issue (see the enumeration of preconditions above). That said, I still see value in discussing, because I may of course overlook things.

---

> I see here you're implicitly expecting client to use a single aud value for your solution to be secured too.

That is not an implicit expectation, the current text very much explicitly says "sole audience value".

> If a client uses the same client_id across all ASes and include all issuers in its aud=[issuer1, issuer2], then it can be screwed too.

If a client issues an assertion that is _intended_ (which is what `aud` expresses) to be valid at multiple ASs, then it shouldn't come as a surprise that this assertion _will_ be valid at (those exact!) multiple ASs - hence, I would not consider that an attack.
That said, _intending_ an authentication credential for multiple ASs (that the client generally has to assume will be issuing different client_ids) is a very strange choice by the client, albeit technically allowed (but will be forbidden by the proposed fixes, not only in this document, but also the proposed updates to RFCs 752x, OIDC, CIBA, ..., which I think is a good thing).

> the alternative fix is meant for a vulnerable client that uses a single aud = token_EP.

I am not sure what you're trying to say here - that the alternative fix is only meant for clients that use single-valued `aud`? For which AS(s)? Or something entirely different?

comments.author: adon-at-work
comments.body:
Let's not go line by line about my previous response. With due respect, I disagree your counterexample serves to invalidate a quick-and-dirty fix, which is meant to be a quick and dirty fix.

---

More importantly, as a reader from the engineering world, if I read OIDC (specifically [section 9](https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-core-1_0.html#ClientAuthentication) and may be also RFC752x), and implemented everything there with AS accepting **only** token EP (note that there're no such Updates/Deprecates header on OIDC docs), I'll be happily declaring that I'm fully standard-compliant. It's unlikely I'd go look at CIBA and RFC9126 (PAR) until there's a need to support those extensions.

And if we read the whole passages from CIBA and RFC9126(PAR) in their entirety, they both recognized there's ambiguity on `aud` value, and thus backward compatibility issues. People can always say I gotta balance resources/risk among priorities other than just security. Putting myself into the shoes of the opposing side, some will likely argue that they're NOT a normative change anyone has to follow or have followed, since (1) they have no Updates/Deprecates header for the older RFC/OIDC; (2) they can be interpreted as extension-specific; (3) the last "MUST" sentence that you quoted is also a conditional statement applicable to those who need/want to facilitate interoperability; and/or (4) the last sentence from CIBA and RFC9126 sound kinda incompatible with each other if I need to support both CIBA and RFC9126. It doesn't mean/matter if I, as a security folk, fully agree, that's just how the world works. You will understand as you enter the industry. :)

From [CIBA](https://openid.net/specs/openid-client-initiated-backchannel-authentication-core-1_0.html#auth_request)

> Note that there's some potential ambiguity around the appropriate audience value to use when JWT client assertion based authentication is employed. To address that ambiguity the Issuer Identifier of the OP SHOULD be used as the value of the audience. To facilitate interoperability, the OP MUST accept its Issuer Identifier, Token Endpoint URL, or Backchannel Authentication Endpoint URL as values that identify it as an intended audience.

From [RFC9126](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9126#section-2-5)

> Due to historical reasons, there is potential ambiguity regarding the appropriate audience value to use when employing JWT client assertion-based authentication (defined in [Section 2.2](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7523#section-2.2) of [[RFC7523](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7523)] with private_key_jwt or client_secret_jwt authentication method names per Section 9 of [[OIDC](http://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-core-1_0.html)]). To address that ambiguity, the issuer identifier URL of the authorization server according to [[RFC8414](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8414)] SHOULD be used as the value of the audience. In order to facilitate interoperability, the authorization server MUST accept its issuer identifier, token endpoint URL, or pushed authorization request endpoint URL as values that identify it as an intended audience.

My two cents. May be I'm wrong, BCP is BCP, technically it's not a standard. No matter what will be written, people might have different opinions on considering anything there as normative changes or not. Regardless, your contribution on writing up a useful BCP is valuable, if possible, take the chance to cleanup the mess. Give a comprehensive guide on how things can be best fixed, and leave no/less ambiguity so people can have excuses. And that's my perhaps naive belief. :)

And so, just as a random reader (who'd appreciate a well-documented reference to use against Goliath :)), I'd love to see:
- at least recognize the ambiguity like CIBA/RFC9126, so people know a client change from token_EP to something else may be a breaking change, since it does not guarantee server acceptance. If it just works, cool!
- the BCP / most recommended `aud` value a client should send. conforming to CIBA and RFC9126, apparently should be the issuer.
- the BCP for AS, what `aud` value should it accept? regardless of whether it's interpreted as normative or just a BCP recommendation. You probably want AS to accept only either issuer or target-specific endpoint URL. I'd argue making it target endpoint specific is never clearly spelled out by any other spec. For instance, PAR endpoint should not take aud=token_EP, and token_endpoint should not take aud=par_EP, unless for interoperability/historical reasons.
- the BCP if just in case a client cannot get all your ASes to comply, then there comes recommendations in decreasing preference. 1. use different (the current draft uses the word "fresh") key material per AS; 2. ensure no overlapping of (client_id, aud) among all supported current and future ASes (unless absolutely required... it's okay to condition that), etc...

They're my little suggestions for you to consider and decide one way or the other. Thanks and appreciate that. :)

issues.title: Make "Updates to Mix-Up Attacks" subsection more self-contained
issues.author: KevinLuo2000
issues.body:
(This is part of the feedback by @adon-at-work on #17, to be resolved by @KevinLuo2000)

> My first impression after reading the first few sections in 2.2 is like it’s written more like attacking RFC9700 4.4 line by line or as if presenting a diff for D Fett’s considerations of updating his spec than targeting someone who has no knowledge about mix-up. The fact that I need to open two specs side-by-side will fail to gain any tractions from engineers IMO. The spec should be much more self-contained, and the requirements to click on a link is optional. It is extremely hard to follow, even for me. 
>
> This new RFC draft implies that we’re no more in the mentality of filing an errata to RFC9700 nor making last minute modification suggestions before RFC9700 was published. Your section 2.3 seems to be starting fresh with a new attack (even claiming a huge scope, as huge as “Attacks in open ecosystems”), which is good.

comments.author: KevinLuo2000
comments.body:
I kept the section title in 2.2 as "Updates to Mix-Up Attacks", but changed the first subvariant of the Per-AS Redirect URIs mix-up (“Advanced Mix-up Attacks”) from a diff to RFC9700 4.4 to a self-contained description.

Also explicitly mentioned the names of two existing defenses to improve readability.

See commit https://github.com/SECtim/draft-wuertele-oauth-security-topics-update/pull/17/commits/fce5556d69f31ee8a00c6c100499d8e4cb4b0b27 and https://github.com/SECtim/draft-wuertele-oauth-security-topics-update/pull/17/commits/c01aa2d173edc62229a8fc1abb8d076240b507e4.

issues.title: Clarify the application scenario and attack scenario of "Open Ecosystems"
issues.author: KevinLuo2000
issues.body:
(This is part of the feedback by @adon-at-work on https://github.com/SECtim/draft-wuertele-oauth-security-topics-update/pull/17, to be resolved by @KevinLuo2000)

**Condense Section 2.3.1 "OAuth in Open Ecosystems" and Section 2.3.2 "Attack Scenario":**

> More generally, quite many content isn’t written like a spec, but more like a blog/paper/story, and it will surprise those who come for a very cold BCP or a spec. Whether it’s traditional/new, less barrier, and how open is irrelevant from spec perspective, they’re more like market trends or just considerations for evaluating security risk/impact only. A link to perhaps a blog for such content (or a presentation talking about reversal) could be good, but they shouldn’t be the main text of the spec. Those information, if absolutely relevant, should be compressed no more than 1 paragraph. I’m afraid the more content you have, the harder it is to get consensus with a broad community. My point is less is better when drafting up the spec.

**Clarify the scope of "Open Ecosystems":**

> I have to also admit that I have a different opinion on DCR. May be I should not accuse it with “no body using it” or “impractical”, when I lately figured the open-banking standard backed by UK gov has DCR standardized (99% similar to OAuth2 DCR as I briefly overviewed). Think about there’s a universal banking app that works across all different (UK) banks. I assume a user can just go to such a universal banking app, choose let’s say HSBC (which under the hood hits HSBC’s DCR) or even directly specify any URL that conforms to the UK open-banking standard. Then the client negotiates some client credential for oauth client authentication, and subsequently launches auth code grant to authenticate the user too. 
> 
> I don’t know whether we should classify it as open-ecosystem, where the app will then speak the same standardized banking protocols regardless of what bank resource servers are. May be they can support bank/issuer-sharing oauth scenarios since even a single user can have multiple bank accounts with a single bank. But it does have certain openness where a user can dynamically feed a new OAuth “client-configuration” at will, and can face COAT attacks. 
> 
> I don’t know how widely adopted that thing is, may be there’s just some part of the world in EU we don’t know enough. Let’s just assume this existed, or may hypothetically exist in the future as a properly valid use case. Hence, I want AS-sharing to be described just as a characteristic by itself, instead of tiring it to and put it under a section of open-ecosystem. 
> 
> One line on AS-sharing, I think, is good and succinct enough to bring up the problem:
> > AS-sharing. a client can use a (honest) AS, with multiple sets of different client credentials (e.g.., client id), for legitimate purposes.
>

comments.author: KevinLuo2000
comments.body:
I have kept the “open ecosystem” terminology and structure, as I do think it better motivates the issuer-sharing mix-up setup and the client configuration confusion attack. With all the recent developments in MCP and reflection on integration platforms, I feel the open ecosystem concept needs a special call-out.
 
To that end, I also generalized the “open ecosystem” definition to make it less specific to Integration Platforms.
See https://kevinluo2000.github.io/TestIETF/draft-wuertele-oauth-security-topics-update.html#name-oauth-in-open-ecosystems.

issues.title: Decide whether to include "Client Configuration Confusion"
issues.author: KevinLuo2000
issues.body:
(This is part of the feedback by @adon-at-work on #17, to be resolved by @KevinLuo2000)

> I don’t have a good idea how 2.3.4 should be structured, but I’m very afraid that may stir up more debate as one may argue it shouldn’t be as an OAuth protocol issue. For argument sake, it’s more a resource server issue, or more like an issue of “open-ecosystem” where access token is given to a resource endpoint controlled by attacker. I want it in, as 2.3, like a section of its own, as I think it’s valuable to the community, but hesitate that people might not be very receptive, and it may take a lot more battles to fight that section in.

comments.author: KevinLuo2000
comments.body:
> For argument sake, it’s ... more like an issue of “open-ecosystem” where access token is given to a resource endpoint controlled by attacker.

Exactly. That's why I'd rather fit the section under the umbrella of "Attacks in Open Ecosystems".

Furthermore, when the resource server URL can be specified at runtime, the threat is called out in RFC9700 Section 4.9.1 ([Access Token Phishing by Counterfeit Resource Server](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9700#name-access-token-phishing-by-co)), with defenses mentioned by Section 4.9.3 ([Countermeasures](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9700#name-countermeasures-8)) such as making access tokens sender-constrained and audience-restricted.

> it’s more a resource server issue

I would say although our "Client Configuration Confusion" is Resource Server-related, it is complementary to the aforementioned threat and defense.
* Threat-wise, we focus on reusing registered clients of an honest AS to exfiltrate access tokens, when the client has no intention of leaking the registered client's tokens to an attacker-controlled resource server.
* Defense-wise, sender-constrained and audience-restricted tokens are sort of like defense-in-depth, while the defense for client configuration confusion is a specific security measure to resolve issues in open ecosystems.

issues.title: Restructure "Mix-up Reloaded"-related Sections
issues.author: KevinLuo2000
issues.body:
(This is part of the feedback by @adon-at-work on #17, to be resolved by @KevinLuo2000)

> With due respect, I recommend the following structure, with contents from 2.3.3 absorbed in appropriate sections.
> 
> I suppose we should write it as a new attack, either we call it Advanced Mix-up Attacks (if you want to honor D Fett) or COAT and CORF Attacks, or even COAT and CORF (aka. Advanced mix-up). As you introduce it, may be we should just say this section 2.2 supersedes mix-up as defined in RFC9700 and/or we should frame there’re n variants, and certain variants is covered by RFC9700.
> 
> **2.2.1 Attack Description**
> “The description here follows RFC9700 section 4.4 (kinda give credit to them), with new variants of the attack outlined below.”
> 
> Preconditions:
> * copy presumptions that are still valid, probably we will use only the first one in 4.4
> * **AS-sharing. a client can use a (honest) AS, with multiple sets of different client credentials (e.g.., client id), for legitimate purposes.** (RFC9700 implicitly assumed/implied otherwise. Just in case a client can guarantee uniqueness of AS, RFC9700 4.4 suffices… I assume this is true. If not, we may point to a discussion section.)
> A final paragraph like “Hence this advanced mix-up requires less assumptions than the mixup in RFC9700.”
> And so we split the discussion into 2 subsections
> 
> **2.2.1.1 Same redirect_uri**
> Same as 4.4.1 + redirect_uri in the attack steps
> Variants:
> * Mix-Up with Interception. (same as 4.4.4.1) still copy their text
> * Implicit Grant(same as 4.4.4.1) still copy their text
> * OpenID Connect(same as 4.4.4.1) still copy their text
> * Naïve… or CORF (new)
> * Whatever other new variant
> 
> **2.2.1.2 Distinct redirect_uri**
> Open this paragraph with why it can still fail, as opposed to understanding in RFC9700.
> Same as 4.4.1 with distinct redirect_uri adjusted accordingly in attack steps
> 
> Variants:
> * Mix-Up with Interception. refer to 2.2.2.1
> * Implicit Grant. refer to 2.2.2.1
> * OpenID Connect. refer to 2.2.2.1
> * Inherit other in 2.2.2.1
> * Add any new, if any
> 
> (new and old) Variants corresponding and unique to distinct redirect_uri.
> 
> **2.2.2 Countermeasures.**
> 2.2.2.1
> When precondition 2 does not hold, or when client has enforced that the AS-sharing condition will NOT exist. One may refer to 4.4.2, except with the following cavets/updates…… this is basically your draft. But please make those suggested defenses split also in bullet form that kinda correspond to Variant list (better if you can come up with a name for them instead of Variant 1,2,3).
> 
> 2.2.2.2
> Given precondition 2, 2.2.1.1 needs to change to use distinct redirect_uri, right?

comments.author: KevinLuo2000
comments.body:
> AS-sharing. a client can use a (honest) AS, with multiple sets of different client credentials (e.g.., client id), for legitimate purposes. (RFC9700 implicitly assumed/implied otherwise. Just in case a client can guarantee uniqueness of AS, RFC9700 4.4 suffices… I assume this is true. If not, we may point to a discussion section.)

I agree, but there maybe some misunderstandings here. Let me clarify:

**On AS-sharing:**
* If a client can guarantee uniqueness of AS, as you said, RFC9700 4.4 suffices, which is true.
* If a client cannot guarantee uniqueness of AS, my claim is, RFC9700 4.4 still suffices (though there is an alternative) in defense (4.4.2), but needs clarifications on the attack descriptions (4.4.1). 

----
For **attack descriptions** (4.4.1), there are some ambiguities in the texts:
> Preconditions: For this variant of the attack to work, it is assumed that
> ...
> * **the client stores the authorization server chosen by the user** in a session bound to the user's browser and uses the same redirection URI for each authorization server.

> Attack on the authorization code grant:
> ...
> 2. **The client stores in the user's session that the user selected "A-AS"** and ...

Implementers may argue that, "storing the _authorization server_ chosen by the user" will break the functional requirement of tracking issuer-sharing client configurations (e.g., sending the correct client credentials to the token endpoint). In other words, for a client to distinguish issuer-sharing client configurations, it cannot (just) store the "authorization server" chosen by the user, but should (also) store the "client configuration". Thus, the attacks in scenarios with shared issuers are simply out of scope of RFC9700 4.4.1, since the preconditions do not hold.

This is the confusing part with the attack description. I tried to clarify it in https://kevinluo2000.github.io/TestIETF/draft-wuertele-oauth-security-topics-update.html#name-attack-description-2.


----
When it comes to **countermeasures** (4.4.2), however, I would argue that 4.4 is sufficient.
The defenses in 4.4.2 requires the client to track each issuer (in a session), and compare with the returned issuer. The defenses do work for issuer-sharing client configurations, because the issuer bind authorization and token endpoints, leaving no room for the infiltration of a malicious endpoint. A client supporting issuer-sharing client configurations can, store the client configuration chosen by the user (for functional needs), and, at the same time, store and compare the returned issuer (for mix-up defense).

Therefore, I suggested the "distinct redirect_uri per client configuration" defense as an _alternative_ to issuer-based defenses. See https://kevinluo2000.github.io/TestIETF/draft-wuertele-oauth-security-topics-update.html#name-countermeasures-2.

comments.author: KevinLuo2000
comments.body:
**Structure:**
> 2.2.1 Attack Description
> 2.2.1.1 Same redirect_uri
> 2.2.1.2 Distinct redirect_uri

While same/distinct redirect_uri do relate to the attack preconditions, IMHO it is not a decisive factor in mix-up, thus I'd rather not treat it as a top-level separation in the attack description. Also, the "distinct" term alone can be unspecified since there are distinct per _issuer_ and distinct per _client configuration_. 


> 2.2.2 Countermeasures.
> 2.2.2.1
> When precondition 2 (AS-sharing) does not hold
> 2.2.2.2
> Given precondition 2 (AS-sharing), ...

I agree with the separation here. I think AS/issuer-sharing should be the decisive factor in defense, and also the attack description. 
- Old World - No issuer-sharing: RFC9700 Section 4.4 + https://kevinluo2000.github.io/TestIETF/draft-wuertele-oauth-security-topics-update.html#section-2.2 .
- New World - With issuer-sharing (Commonly seen in Open Ecosystems): https://kevinluo2000.github.io/TestIETF/draft-wuertele-oauth-security-topics-update.html#section-2.3.3.

comments.author: KevinLuo2000
comments.body:
**Clarification:**
> 2.2.2.2
> Given precondition 2, 2.2.1.1 (Attack Description - Same redirect_uri) needs to change to use distinct redirect_uri, right?

Not really. With same redirect_uri, a client could:
* store each client configuration in a session (to fulfill functional requirement), AND
* store each issuer in a session (maybe associated with stored client configuration thus no need of extra storage in session), AND
* match with returned issuer identifier following RFC9207 (to fulfill security requirement a.k.a. mix-up defense).

This can be done without changing to use distinct redirect_uri.

comments.body:
Based on Section 4.1.3 of RFC7519, the very generic clause of how `aud` can be used, it sounds like you're saying the authorization servers are expected to **readily** accept `aud={issuer}`, `aud={token_endpoint}`, `aud={revoke_endpoint}`, `aud={par_endpoint}` etc that identify themselves. Is this realistic though, when most other specs were suggesting clients to send `aud={token_endpoint}`?

My two cents. Think about I'm building a client that wants to support 3 servers. It's always better to define a clear (and standardized) contract between clients and servers. A client then needs to not to maintain a map like serverA can only take `token_endpoint`, while server B&C accept only `issuer` (nowhere this is communicated through openid/oauth metadata??).

From a (pure) spec perspective, the AS is ready to accept these values due to the very generic language in RFC 7519. For some endpoints like PAR and CIBA, that's also explicitly required by the respective specs (see the discussion in #13). I.e., there are no _normative_ changes to the AS, which is what the current text says.

That said (and taking into consideration the engineer perspective): What is your proposal? Should the text explicitly say that even though there as no normative changes, a concrete AS implementation may need to be adapted? Or are you suggesting to make normative changes, i.e., _requiring_ as AS to (only?) accept its issuer identifier and/or the exact endpoint as `aud`, even though that's not strictly necessary to prevent the attack?

> It's always better to define a clear (and standardized) contract between clients and servers. A client then needs to not to maintain a map like serverA can only take token_endpoint, while server B&C accept only issuer

The current text actually does this (albeit not in a normative way) - it basically says: If you as a client use Discovery/AS Metadata with that AS, then use the issuer identifier; otherwise, use the exact endpoint URI (as the sole `aud` value in both cases). The AS can safely accept both (or, for example, require its clients to always use AS Metadata, and hence, the issuer identifier, as is the case, e.g., for FAPI 2.0 SP).

Do you propose to make this distinction (AS Metadata/Discovery => Issuer Identifier; otherwise => exact endpoint) an explicit normative requirement?
We tried to avoid that to leave ecosystems the option to, e.g., always use the issuer identifier, even if they don't use AS Metadata/Discovery (in which case the client needs to validate the "issuer identifier to endpoints" mapping out of band, but getting AS information out of band, e.g., by configuration, is a common practice anyway; and the language in #15 clearly requires clients to actually validate this mapping).
Note that leaving this option open is also necessary to not create a conflict with the OAuth WG's 7523-bis draft and the current text for an OIDC errata that require clients to use the issuer identifier (regardless of whether the AS Metadata/Discovery mechanism is used).

>  (nowhere this is communicated through openid/oauth metadata??).

True, it currently isn't and never was - this problem isn't new. Actually, this is another reason for expecting that many of the ASs that rely on clients getting all required metadata via AS Metadata/Discovery will already be pretty liberal in what they accept as `aud`.

pulls.title: First draft of Mix-up Reloaded Work
pulls.author: KevinLuo2000
pulls.body:
Resolves #3.

Preview: https://kevinluo2000.github.io/TestIETF/draft-wuertele-oauth-security-topics-update.html

Currently, I separated the mix-up updates that are open ecosystem-agnostic (Section 2.2) from those that have to do with the open ecosystem/issuer-sharing setting (Section 2.3.1-2.3.3), and added a preliminary draft on the newly-developed RS mix-up idea (Section 2.3.4, now referred to as “Client Configuration Confusion Attack”).

The contents are based on:

- Our original proposed updates to IETF [Dec 2024-Jan 2025]
- Feedback from Aaron, Daniel, Guido, and others at OAuth Security Workshop [Feb 2025]
    - Especially, clearly define what constitutes an integrated “app”, and use an alternative term to avoid the confusion with what an “application“ usually stands for in OAuth
- Follow-up discussions (mainly with @SECtim) in the OAuth Security Workshop’s \#mix-up-attacks Slack channel [Mar-Apr 2025]
as well as invaluable insights/feedback from one-on-one discussions/group meeting with @adon-at-work @SECtim @PedramHD , and my research group.

Note that I still have some unresolved comments from @adon-at-work side, regarding the structure and writing style. I will post them as GitHub issues and start resolving them in the upcoming days.

reviews.author: SECtim
reviews.body:
Thanks for this extensive PR! I like the writing style and (most of the) structure. 
Please interpret my comments as suggestions (of varying importance) - if there's need for discussion on some (or all) of them, we can just move them to issues and merge this PR nonetheless, so we can get a first individual I-D out soon.

Hence my approval despite the many comments :smile:

comments.body: With all due respect, it does not look to me like Adonis provided substantial text to this draft (but please correct me if I am wrong about this!). Reviewing a draft is commonplace in the IETF, reviewers are then usually listed in the acknowledgments section.

This gets rendered as `Authors, M. C. P. S.` in the reference section. Can we just supply an `ins` element with the full `Model Context Protocol Specification Authors` again?
I did not really check the MCP spec for different authorship information, but maybe we can instead list an organization or smth. similar here?

> it is implicitly assumed that each authorization server has only one client configuration at a client

I know what you mean by that and with the above definition of "client configuration", all the information is there to understand this statement - but I think this might confuse readers not already familiar with the topic, because in the traditional setting, a client "has a configuration" at an AS, not the other way round. Maybe it is possible to express this in terms of the traditional OAuth model, e.g.,

> In traditional OAuth deployments, it is implicitly assumed that there is exactly one client configuration for each client-authorization server pair.

A more tangible example might help readers to get on the right (mental) track, e.g.,

> ... associated authorization servers at development time (e.g., in integration platforms, where external services register themselves as authorization and resource servers with a platform that acts as a client, see {{research.cuhk}})

... maybe even more concrete?

It might be helpful for readers to explicitly say something along the lines of "in what we refer to as open ecosystems, the registration roles are reversed: ..." at the beginning of that paragraph.

Thinking about it, I am not sure I agree with defining "open ecosystems" as

> protected resources accessible to a client are configured beyond the discretion of the client or client developers

... because deciding what is accessible to a client is up to the AS/RS/RO in the traditional OAuth model as well. Or am I missing something here? Is there a good reason to not define "open ecosystems" via the "reversed registration" characteristic?

At this point, readers do not yet know what "issuer sharing" is, I guess that's the reason for the "(explained below)". I suggest putting "(explained below)" or "(see below)" right after "issuer-sharing", so readers don't get hung up on this term.

> Under this assumption, the issuer serves as a unique identifier for the client.

I think we should be very explicit about what we mean by "the issuer" in this context (because that's exactly where the problem is).

```suggestion
In traditional OAuth deployments, it is implicitly assumed that each authorization server has only one client configuration at a client. Under this assumption, the issuer (as defined in {{Section 4.4.2 of !RFC9700}}) serves as a unique identifier for the client. This has led to the common practice of clients tracking "the authorization server chosen by the user" during OAuth flows, as well as the adoption of existing mix-up defenses ({{Section 4.4.2 of !RFC9700}}), all of which are based on the issuer concept that uniquely identifies each authorization server.
```

> all of which are based on the issuer concept that uniquely identifies each authorization server.

I suggest adding (at the end):

> all of which are based on the issuer concept that uniquely identifies each authorization server from the client's point of view. However, crucially, the issuer does not uniquely identify a client configuration as defined above.

This section is labeled "Attack Description", but I don't think anyone not already familiar with the topic will have a good understanding of the attack after reading this section.
It feels like the stage is set by explaining that open ecosystems extend the RFC 9700 scenario, but the remaining paragraphs don't really explain the actual attack.
I think the current state makes sense.

```suggestion
4. The client redeems the code issued by H-AS at H-AS's token endpoint. To authenticate with H-AS, the client creates a client assertion signed by itself. Recall that both A-Config and H-Config registered the client with H-AS under the same client ID, and that the client uses the same key pair for authentication at H-AS. Hence, this client assertion, if required, would be a valid authentication credential for the client at H-AS. Generating client assertions in this step is of course only relevant for confidential clients.
```

Public clients cannot authenticate (by definition, see Sec. 2 of RFC 6749).

Thanks for the question!
While the commits were pushed by me, I worked closely with Adonis when producing the texts (we work as a team and communicate via email and weekly meetings), so his contribution went beyond a reviewer role. 
After we publish the first version of I-D, he may also directly edit the spec through PRs, which I'm sure will make our sections more engineer-friendly.

Good catch!

"Model Context Protocol is an open source project run by [Anthropic, PBC.](https://anthropic.com/) and open to contributions from the entire community."

MCP an open protocol first introduced by Anthropic but contributed by the broader community. I'll use Anthropic as author in the reference for now and update it if needed later.
Sure, marked as resolved.

> However, crucially, the issuer does not uniquely identify a client configuration as defined above.

I'm not sure if we should at it under this "traditional OAuth deployments" paragraph. 

In traditional OAuth deployments, there is exactly one client configuration for each client-authorization server pair. So if we are only talking about uniqueness/unique identifier, from the client's point of view, issuer==client configuration==authorization server.

When I wrote this paragraph, I was referring to section 2.3 of RFC6749, where there is a MAY for public clients:
> The authorization server MAY establish a client authentication method with public clients.  However, the authorization server MUST NOT rely on public client authentication for the purpose of identifying the client.

That said, I've updated as what you suggested.

Agree. The "Attack Description" did not really explain how an attack can be mounted.

I've now included the full description of a mix-up attack variant in such open ecosystem setting.
Nice suggestion.

This is a good point and I do have some special considerations in the wording.
Will come back to this later.
